text: 750 ml bottle @ Radikal whale slaying, Thessaloniki. Thanks Dylan! Almost clear orange color with off white head. Yeasty and light malty aroma, funky, dusty, barnyard, tart citrusy fruity, floral-grassy. Light sweet and moderate acidic taste. Light to medium oily body with soft carbonation.
Magnum 2007 Vintage- pours gold white head - nose/taste of peppery funk, lemon, oak, horse funk - medium body
Magnum. Golden pour with white head. Sweet, malty, light funk flavors. Oak, funk, wine, leather and barn yard aromas.

(750ml bottle, #99/200, 2007) Pours a clear copper body with a medium bubbly white head. Aroma of barnyard, horse blanket, grapefruit peel, earth, and lemon zest. Flavor of grapefruit, sour white grapes, some passion fruit seeds, and some dry woodiness in the finish.
Sample from bottle. Pours clear light orange. Aroma bit sour, fruity. Taste only bit sour, dry finish, bit fruity.
Okay in aroma and flavor. Very well done. Body is perfect for the style. Unusually easy drinking

Poured from a big ass bottle @ Bills 40th birthday. This was my second favorite beer of the day after Tilquin Gueuze. Hazy yellow appearance with a white head. Aroma is full of funk, cheese, cobwebs, barn, and a bit of dust. Nice carbonation and acidity. Very refreshing. Nice lactic element that is well-balanced. Some earth / grass. No hint of the 8% booze. Really good.

Pour from 3L at the Barrel Cellar for Bills 40th. Thanks man! Pour is hazy orange with a big white head and good lacing. Big funky, sweet tarts, lemony, uriney, oaky, cobwebs, horse blanket, and pepper in the aroma. Taste is funky, cheesy, waxy, lemony, oaky, peppery, tannic, uriney, and floral with a lightly tart finish. Medium body with medium carbonation. Delicious.

Sample at SBWF 2015. 

Golden with a white head. Nicely sour with grapes, wood, citrus and hints of brett. Refreshing and with lively carbonation.

Bottle. Unclear golden in color with a whitish head. Stable, apple skin, some funky and earthy notes in aroma. Fruits, apples and barnyard in taste. Sour notes, more barnyard and wood in aftertaste. Quite good one.

Golden colour, white head. Aroma of citrus, white wine, lemon peel, funky notes. Mild sour flavour, candy, lemon zest, apricot. Malty finish, citrus peel. Good presentation in the magnum bottle. Decent geuze, but was rather expecting it to be a bit more than that.(from 1.5L magnum bottle @ THT: Hey Julien is back and Deans floor is moist Tasting. Thanks for sharing, kermis!!)
Bottle at THT tasting. Clear golden pour, thin white head. Aroma of brett, some fruits, citrus and slightly spicy. Flavor is quite sour, bretty and with quite some carbonation. Nice.

Magnum at THT. Clear orange golden with big fluffy white head. Sour grains and grapes, leaves, quite sugary, lots of spices, very champagne like actually, twigs, gooseberries. Taste is light sour, under medium sweet and finishes light bitter. Medium bodied with sparkly champagne like carbonation. Hmm, not bad but a bit disappointing.

Magnum bottle shared. Pours hazy amber orange with a medium off white head. Aroma of typical Oud Beersel funk, citrus, cobwebs and light cellar notes. Flavour is light to light moderate sweet (I wish that wasnt there!) and moderate sour. Light medium bodied with some sweet almost malt notes coming out in the palate with the lambic. Light carbonation. Decent but I wish the sweetness wasnt there.

Magnum sampled at September THT.
Thin white head. Barnyard funk aroma. Hazy golden pour. Tart sourness.

2011 Magnum shared by Adam C on 7/25/15.Fairly foamy white head shows poor retention atop a dull golden body that has a good clarity.Odd sweetness in the nose has hints of vanilla cookies with very tart, boisterous brett esters. So its kinda sweet and fruity....Pineapple, hickory nut skin, lemon....but just too much sugary sweetness, even from the nose. Late sharpness/heat from too much alcohol, but its not obnoxious. Other than the powdered/cookie-like sugars, its passable, if very uninspiring, just like its friend Bzart Oude Lambic.Flavor is a bit better, I guess? Though theres a weird sugar-meets-cooked-meat sorta thing. Plenty of acidity, lots of lighthearted citrus and a very, very thin texture, despite it being amply carbonated. Again, not horrendous, but with so many amazing lambics out there, the fact that this stuff is like ~50 bucks a bottle on average in America is just laughable. Some people like these softer, sweeter, more approachable lambics and thats fine, but I hate them.  If I want malt, Ill go drink a stout, thanks just the same.  Cant even bring myself to buy the kriekenlambic, though Ive never had it. They have it at Downtown Wine and Spirits for the bargain price of $65.....

Yet, another Magnum during the big magnum tasting, thanks Adam. 2011 vintage. Aroma is oak, lambic yeast giving that mild baby diaper nuance. Light funky cheese. 
Flavor has the light oak upfront with a good amount of sweet grain or malt ( cant tell because of the mild baby diaper hints).but its not shitty diaper, so it has that gong for it. Mouthfeel has some mild acidic notes. Dry texture. I like it more then I thought I would.
Magnum shared by AdamChandler, opened at Ratebeer Farmhouse Magnum Tasting v1. Pours orange brown with an off white head. Aroma is baby fresh. Flavor is oak, cherry skin, pencil bitter in the finish.

Poured from magnum thanks AdamChandler for the Ratebeer Farmhouse Magnum Tasting. Pours hazy golden with a foamy white head. Aromas of wild yeast funk and citrus peel and vinegar. Taste is woody with notes of grass and mineral.

18.07.2015, 0,75l bottle (Milleisme 2007, #42/200) shared @ BBGTC tasting:
Huge fizzy-creamy longlasting head. Aroma is slightly dry and funky, oak, weeds, bark, brett, hay, old rope, old cellar, sorrel. Taste is slightly dry sour-ish, oak, sorrel, vinegar, minerals, grass, old rope, old cellar, weeds, bark. Medium bitterness, dry sour-ish mouthfeel. Nice.

Bottle shared with BBGTC. Hazy golden with a white top. Aroma is wild bretty with red currant jelly and loads of horse stables. Taste is tart with pungent wheat, stables and dry hay. Medium bosy and high co2 levels.

Bottle, shared with BBGTC. Pours a deep clear copper-hued golden body with a large, fast-disappearing white head. Nose is extreme bretty stable tones, citric peel, lemon juice, apple vinegar, hay and hints of straw, red berries and balsamic. Taste is heavy bretty stable notes, red berries, metallic grassy hop tones, straw and hints of lime, acetic acid and mild pale malts. Light body, high carbonation. One of the most bretty geuzes Ive had, enjoyable but highly remarkable.

Bottle at Dads for the half marathon tasting. Pours a hazed amber with a thin white head. Musk, soft acid. Medium bodied, big tart funky acid, horsy with some big funk. Cheesy funky acid, long musk and chewy yeast. Gorgeous. Grainy

Pours a deep clear orange, fluffy off white head. Aroma is heavy oak, sour cherry, grape, faint tart apple, light lacto. Flavor is exceptionally well balanced, lots of oak, tart fruits, cedar, lacto / med sour. Everything about this is smooth and enjoyable. Great oude gueze.

Bottle courtesy of James at the half marathon tasting - may 16th. Pours a deep hazy orange with active white lacing. Aroma is lightly herbal, funky fruit and sour character. Mouthfeel is medium and tart with notes of herbal tart character, oak, sour fruit and light mineral character. The champagne yeast works well.

bottle shared at a bzart tasting with a few colleagues, poured a dark yellow cloudy colour with a white head. lemons, wheat, notes of pepper spice of the brett, wood, apples, barnyard, im getting some kind of a grape in the end, slight acid, balanced beer, yet very overpriced compared with other geuzes
Yellow hazy with small head. Sour aroma. Sour taste with minimal sweetness and fruity notes. Slightly sour aftertaste.

January 24, 2015. Bottled 2011. Shared by tderoeck, thanks Tim! 
Hazy pale amber with a small white head. Aroma is citrus, green apples, earthy and dusty with faint notes of nail polish. Taste is tart apples, citrus, light sweet and some barnyard notes. Medium bodied, average carbonation.

Courtesy of Benzai. The geuze in this weird yet fascinating series of champagne yeast experiments, produced at Oud Beersel. Sticky, lacing, off-white head, hazy orange blonde colour. Rich and funky aroma with all the complexity one expects from a traditional geuze; sweaty, cellary, utterly estery, peach, walnuts, vanilla, sherry, wet hay, old cheese... Very estery, vivid lambic fruitiness in the mouth, very complex with a pointy, refreshing tartness, lemony acidity, brut mouthfeel, yeasty with indeed a champagne-like flavour in the back, long and complex drying tart finish with woody hints and lingering sourness. An unusual, but very good geuze indeed.
Bottle from tderoeck, many thanks! Cloudy yellow colour, white foam. Aroma of tart apples and some citrus. Light bitterness. Crispy and well balanced. Refreshing. Very good geuze!

Thanks to Benzai for this one! 750 ml. bottle. 1/4th consumed @ Tim needs to get rid of his ticks Tasting. Enjoyed together with tderoeck, Benzai & Alengrin. Clear darker amber, fluffy big bubbly head is all over the place. Nose is orange peel, crispy funk, old rustic lambiek with a hint of malt sweetness, bergamot & lively citrus. Taste is old malty lambiek with light bitterness, lightly lactic, orange peel, bergamot, orange peel, thick horseblanket. Very high carbonation. Quite lovely. The best I have had from Oud Beersel.

Bottle shared with tderoeck, Alengrin and 77ships @ Tim needs to get rid of his ticks tasting. Clear dark apple juice like color. Head can differ from huge to minimal. Aroma is sourish, leather, rubber, horse blanket. Ah well, as expected. Tastes about the same with a touch of fruit added while the leather, rubber and horse blanket faint. Moderate to heavy sour, medium body, a bit fizzy carbonation.

Bottle says 2007 Lambic. 75CL purchased in Belgium. Enjoyed @ 40F after this rested for about a year in the cellar. Split 2 ways in a Gueuze tumbler.

A - Pretty cloudy for a Gueuze. A very burnt orange, 4 finger tight creamy white head that faded slowly to 2 fingers.

S - Lots of lemon on the nose, a bit sulphur and wheat with some creamy aspects. Its strange but after walnuts, I get this fresh cut pine, woodshed, construction site wood smell. it smells like a damn, Home Depot.

T - This is very lemon forward, loads of sourdough bread and a nice earthy quality. Lots of grape skins, a bit of pepper. Theres a lot going on here and its really quite nice. 

M - Great mouthfeel, sharp acidic grapefruit with champagne and a nice fruity finish

O - I was really impressed by this beer. Happy I have a LOT more of this stockpiled. Itll do great things in the future.

Magnum shared at Salud Bottle Shop in Charlotte for their pre-sour fest warm-up. Hazy to cloudy golden yellow color, large fluffy white head. Aroma of dusty, funky summer fruit. Taste has mild barnyard funk, decent complexity, nice fruitiness. Tasty.

Bottled. Pours clear and pale golden with a large, white head. Aroma of brett, apples, spicey tones, barnyard and notes of citrus. Sweet flavor that ends up dry and tart. Light bodied, watery texture and lively carb. A nice Geuze indeed.
Magnum. Pours a clear golden with huge foam. Aroma is nutty, caramel some oak and apple. Light vinegar also. Taste is bretty and rustic, oak and apple sourness. High carbonation. Good one.

Magnum.
Pours light amber with medium-high diminishing off-white head. Aroma is of barnyard, funk, citrus, fruits. Taste is of very nice fruits, citrus, funk, barnyard, very slight hints of sour caramel. Finish a tad metallic. Palate: heavy carbonation. Light-medium body. Overall: Surprisingly heavy carbonation. A bit metallic. Oxydized a bit? Some acetone?

Big pour out of a big bottle, this is nice to live big! ;) Nose is of vinegar and funk, a bit too acetic maybe but still really gueuze-like. Taste is of granny smith, light acetic and really dry. Body was medium and carbonation really, really high. This was fun to drink and different, a lot better than the lambiek we had last year!

magnum shared by julienhuxley, thanks bro. pours hazy dark golden with a champagne-like frothy white head, collapsing slowly but surely and leaving strong lacing. peppery and musty bretts, almost juicy peppery apricots, grannies, hint of tropical notes, light to medium acidity - citric, then the other usual suspects, some cherries, sweetish toasted wheat, fairly oaky. foamy carbonation - just a tad disturbing, light to medium body - feels a tad heavy, drying grassy-peppery and assertively tart finish. good!

Magnum. Shared by JulienHuxley, thanks! Hazy dark golden with a huge slowly diminishing white head and a lot of bubbles. Aroma is minty with light funk, caramel notes and musty notes. Taste is of caramel, minty notes, acetic presence, wood, alcohol and cheesy notes. Full bodied. High/lively carbonation. Dry finish. A tad too heavy from what I like of a gueuze because it hinder drinkability. Aroma is very enticing, similar to the fantastic Oud Beersel Oude Gueuze 07.

Magnum bottle shared at tasting. Deep gold pour, with thick bubbly white head. Aroma is reminiscent of 2007 Oud Beersel Oude Gueuze but with stronger buttery notes, caramel, wet hay, light acetic notes, a bit heavier than the regular 2007. Taste is sour, slightly acetic, grainy flavor, lots of wet grain , light sweetness that makes is a tad heavy. Palate is med bodied with good carbonation. Nice.
Bottle thanks to Eric. Pours a hazy yellow with small frothy head that diminishes quickly. The aroma is strong funk, rubber, oak, wood. Thin mouthfeel with light funk, wheat, oak, with dry finish.

Bottle... darkguardians & biggsbowlers West Palm Beach Birthday Bash!... Mostly clear amber ale with a huge, frothy, white head. Great retention. Smells funky and musky with an undercurrent of citrus rinds. The flavor is funky and tart with yeasty bitterness and an unusually large malty component for a geuze. Still, nicely balanced. Finishes funky and tangy with a kiss of honey. Mad props to darkguardian for sharing this treat!

750ml bottle shared thanks to Lukaduke! Pours semi-clear pale gold with huge 3 finger head. Nose is tart fruity citrus, grain, lemon, light funk. Taste is tart lemon, lime, grains, citrus, fruity yeast, almost saison-like. Finish is dry fruity brett, funk, light yeasty spice. Enjoyable and pleasant, but not the amazing experience one would expect with that pricetag.

Bottle: Served in a Chouffe glass:
Hazy dark orange colored beer with a medium sized creamy foamy head on top.
Aromas of manure, barn, dried grains, old malts, old hops, some wild yeast, older flowers, yeast, wood and light stingy.Quite complex!
Flavours of lovely dusty tartness with cheese, wild yeast, stingy, wood, some dried herbs, grapes, older wood, some herbs and barnyard. Very nice!
Aftertaste is a mix of wild yeast, wood, manure, grains, herbs, wood and some barnyard...
Low to medium carbo, light creamy mouthfeel, medium to full bodied and a light creamy texture.
Very well balanced. A year of rest makes this a great beer!
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text: Bottle. Pours a clear golden color with a small off-white head. Has a frutiy woody funky sour aroma. Fruity funky sour tart woody flavor. hAs a fruity woody funky tart sour finish.
Monster bottle at WTWBA. Orange / yellow pour. Tart apple, some sour. Funky barnyard. Tasty.

Bottle, bought @ De Hopduvel, Gent. Pours clear deep golden with a large, frothy, off-white head. Soon gone. Aroma has sweet malts, funk, apples. Highish carbonation, fine dry and fairly creamy mouthfeel. Flavour has good tartness, funk, apple, sour, dry and light sticky. Warming finish.

#400 rating! Bottle at EBT2 2013. Shared with Mathieu87 and Joris.
APPEARANCE: dark blond beer, huge unstable white head.
NOSE: sourness, barnyard, horse blanket, quite some grains, wood, quite fruity.
TASTE: wood, sourness comes in after, some "earth", little heavy for a Gueuze, quite some carbonation, nice sourness, quite fruity.
Would probably be better with some age?

Huge, fast dwindling off-white head over amberish-brown coloured, very carbonated beer. Tannines, old wood, lactic acid, Brett, horseblanket - all the best and very intense. Wood, tannines, yet sweetish beer, sulphur, Brett/horseblanket, leathergrease. Lemony acidity on the lips. Feels very spritzy, yet not fizzy, light body, acidthinning. Oh wow. This is really a topgueuze - Im impressed. Abject thanks to the donator!

This is a great example of a sour beer, I was lucky enough to get a really fresh bottle, although I think this beer would age really nicely. It has a great sour flavor with a little bit of earthiness to it. This is a great food beer, I had it with a nice lemon chicken, and it brought out more flavors and made the beer even easier to drink.

Bottle shared by Darkguardian an his birthday bash.  Clear yellow pour with a small white head.  Funk and citrus aromas.  Tart lemon and citrus notes.  Decent body and mouthfeel.  Lacks the personality of Cantillon or 3 Fonteinen.

Hazy golden orange body, large white head and soapy lacing. Chesse, must, feet, lemon, and more funky cheese.  Hints of oxidation and acetic apples.  Medium bodied, fairly lactic and acetic, aggressive carbonation, muddled finish.  Not good enough to command the exorbitant price.

Bottle at Delirium Hoppy Loft, pours a hazy golden / copper with a large white head. Aroma of loads of barnyard funk, some tart notes and a bit of a vinous quality. Flavour is fairly acidic, with notes of white wine, mild vinegar, loads of acidic notes, classic barnyard gueuze notes and some champagne notes. Very lively carbonated like champagne, with a prominent acidity and low-to-medium funk. Great stuff, but I dont see how this warrants the premium price.

Bottle at Jack and Leightons Birthday Beeorama, thanks to Matteo for this one, 13/04/13. 2007 bottle.
Lightly hazed golden amber with a thin off white head.
Nose is sour grapes, lemon rind, wood, funky farmy tarteness.
Taste comprises acrid sour fruits, lemon, wood, funky notes.
Medium bodied, a little OTT spritzym dry finish flip flops a la Gandhi!
Decent Gueuze.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Bottle shared at CBC Clerkenwell, London during the Birthday Celebration of Jack & Leighton - big thanks to Matteo, the Lambic Man. Pours amber-gold with a moderate, white foam head. Big grassy funk pervades. Light to medium sweet flavor with further grass, some doughy malts. Medium bodied with average carbonation. Lightly warming to finish, with good sourness and acidity, slight butter and dough, grassy bitterness. Good stuff.

17/IV/13 - 75cl bottle @ De Hopduvel (Gent) @ home - BB: n/a - lagered: XI/2011 - dégorgé: XII/2012 - bottle #012/200 (2013-334) Thanks to Bobochamp for sharing the bottle! 
Clear light orange beer, small irregular off-white head, unstable, non adhesive. Aroma: very distinguishable bretta, dry and woody, a bit off, chemical, rotting wood. MF: lots of carbon, medium body. Taste: sour citric start, lemony, vinegar, woody, apple skin, goose berries, little bitter. After taste: apple skin, lemon, very bitter for a geuze, woody and dry yet unpleasant finish.

Bottle. Cheers to Matteo for the pour. The appearance is light amber with a small white head. The aromas huge feta and bleu cheese. A bit of stinky feet and body odor. Quite a bit of earthy funk. A friend described this as old raclette, which is pretty spot on. Quite tart and aggressive flavors. Hints of raspberry and lemon peel. Earthy wild yeast. Mild pillowy brett. Lightly acetic on the finish. Medium body, full carbonation. Overall, not a particularly nuanced beast. Still, pretty decent.

EPIC thanx to bobochamp for sharing another great beer with me ! 
bottle 012/200 , this is ( as far as i can understand it ) the oude geuze 20078 , 1 year in oak , 5 year refermented in bottle , 1 year bearing .... something like that.. 

anyway , pours clear, blonde, big white foam , smells very funky, tastes very funky, sour, very full body , dough , very dry. damn, amazing good mouthfeel and taste, this might be (one of ) the best geuze ive had so far !

Rating #3000, shared by teorn88. It pours golden yellow with a medium white head. The nose is cheesy (along the lines of parmesan & raclette), earth, sweat, light tartness and Granny Smith apple. The taste is initially tart, lemon, light acidic notes, sherbet, sour white grape, hay, faint farmyard and clean sharpness with a dry, tart finish. Medium body and high carbonation. Carbonation is a bit too high in my opinion and detracts from the mouth-feel. A tasty gueuze, but doesnt have a particularly great depth of flavour.

75cl, Vintage 2007, Bottle 12/200, new exclusive brew Anno 2013, from De Hopduvel Gent, very complex sour brew, woody/sour and slightly vinous/fruity, very balanced, clear, rocky head, very good and original brew, yet very expensive!

75cl bottle shared at CBC Clerkenwell. Loud pop once again, but no gushing. It pours hazy amber with a huge white head that sticks around. Good lacing foam. Aroma is is a great collection of off-flavours upon opening: loads of blue cheese, sweat, feet and basement. Nice. Also has citrus, funk and a good level of acidity. As it opens in the glass, the off-flavours fade a bit leaving behind only some hints of blue cheese. This makes room for the funky notes to really shine and add some complexity to the brew. Aroma is sour and funky, with flavours along the lines just described. Citrus, funk, basement, sweet-acidic. Mouthfeel is medium with high carbonation. Certainly a great beer, but I was a bit surprised that someone liked this more than the Zomer.

2007 Bottle year; Conditioning date of 11/2011; degorgement date of 12/2012; Bottle 016/200; Sampled April 2013.
A very soft pour into my New Belgium globe glass produces a four finger thick, pale tan colored head. The beer is a dark amber color that shows a brilliantly clear, light amber hue when held up to the light. The aroma smells malty somehow, perhaps this is some oxidation character, cidery but not really, definitely a bit tart, some piquant urea notes, a slight musty, woody, oak character, and, once you start digging around, a phenolic character to the finish that leans at first towards cleaning products and then plastic. There is a bit of a saw dust like character to the nose as it warms up.

Effervescent and well carbonated up front, the beer finishes with a tart / sour character, and also has a lingering, though light, cider like note to it. Slightly astringent, with a definite woodiness to it, the beer also has an oxidized / aged malt character that leans towards toasted nuts, slight sherry, a sort of caramelized character (from oxidation and not crystal malts), and perhaps even a hint of cardboard. The finish has a hint of alcohol spiciness to it, but also has a suggestion of antiseptic spray, as well as some mustiness and a certain mustiness to it. Fairly light bodied, but it does have a touch of the palate presence that a good Gueuze should have, though not quite enough, but I do like the effervescent sparkle that the Champagne conditioning has given this.

Not bad, but it certainly seems to lose something with the extra oxidation; this does add some complexity, but that speaks more to the base Gueuze being a bit on the simplistic side than being a compliment. Still this is a Gueuze, and it is decent enough for me to enjoy, though it is definitely my least favorite of the three Bzarts that I have had. I do wonder at the 2007 date, if this was barrel aged for 4 or 5 years before the bottling process I think this was a bit of a mistake; a younger, more vibrant Lambic base, without the oxidation would have been more up my alley. The oxidation isnt overwhelming here, it is just that it is a bit out of place in a decent Gueuze, so sticks out a bit in this beer.

Bottle, 03/12/2013. Pours burnished copper, huge foamy head dies down to manageable size on the surface rather quickly, light lacing and small champagne geysers. Aroma is light sour malts with citrus flesh and red fruit, lactic notes, bit of leather, deep earthy barnyard. Taste attacks initially with sharp tart and funky burst, then citrus and bitter grapefruit with a touch of honey, medium acidity, soft sour quality and oak in a long dry finish. Sparkling palate, yet still coats the tongue after a while to give some depth. Wasnt expecting too much after the Lambiek, this was very pleasant surprise.
Darker than a geuze, with a much more subtle sparkle. Clear hints of white fruit (pear, apple) to complement the typical geuze aromas. Bottle 21/200.
